Graphical abstract The hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol is investigated over a tetrametallic Cu/CoOx/MgO/Al2O3 catalytic system. Activity and characterization results suggest the specific roles of each metal: Cu0 dissociates H2, whereas CoOx, as a reducible oxide, generates Coδ+ sites next to oxygen vacancies where furfuryl alcohol adsorbs. Activated hydrogen spills over from Cu0 to these coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ sites, enabling the hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol. Furthermore, Cu0 aids in the reduction of Co oxide species at lower temperatures during the catalyst activation, thereby promoting the generation of uncoordinated Coδ+ sites. The presence of MgO decreases overall acidity, resulting in reduced hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 2-methylfuran and increased selectivity towards 1,5-pentanediol. Finally, the presence of Al2O3 in the catalyst enhances metal dispersion, reducing the furanic ring hydrogenation to yield tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. With the optimized catalyst, a 43.8% 1,5-pentanediol yield is obtained at 160 °C for 4 h in ethanol, achieving a TOF of 27.4 mol1,5-PDO mol−1 A.S. h−1. Keywords Furfural Oxygen vacancy Direct conversion Hydrotalcite Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) is a versatile chemical building block used in the synthesis of polyesters, polyurethanes, coatings, inks, perfumes, and plasticizers [1,2]. 1,5-PDO ranks as one of the most prized chemical compounds, with a global market of 47.05 USD million in 2022, and it is anticipated to reach 54.70 USD million by 2029 [3]. It is currently produced through the catalytic hydrogenation of glutaric acid, involving toxic chemicals such as potassium cyanide and relying on petroleum-based routes [4]. The production and applications are limited due to high costs and restricted availability of C5 petrochemical feedstocks [5]. Nevertheless, 1,5-PDO can alternatively be produced from furfural (FUR) as biomass-derived feedstock [6]. FUR is a key platform chemical obtained from the hydrolysis and subsequent dehydration of xylan, a polysaccharide present in lignocellulosic biomass [7,8]. The abundant availability and low cost of lignocellulosic biomass make FUR an attractive platform chemical for the production of high value-added products such as 1,5-PDO, 2-methylfuran (2-MF) [9], 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PDO) [10,11], and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) [12,13]. Moreover, a lower CO2 footprint is expected for the biomass-based routes compared to petroleum-based routes [5]. Consequently, the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass into 1,5-PDO is a promising approach for developing a sustainable chemical process. 1,5-PDO can be produced through three main pathways from furfuryl alcohol (FAL) as a FUR hydrogenation derivative (Fig. 1 ): (i) hydrogenation of FAL to THFA and subsequent ring-opening hydrogenolysis [14,15], (ii) direct ring-opening hydrogenolysis of FAL [16–18], and (iii) sequential dehydration–hydration–hydrogenation route via THFA, dihydropyran (DHP), and 2-hydroxytetrahydropan (2-HY-THP) [19–21]. Current research primarily focuses on the two-step THFA approach. For the THFA ring-opening, a well-stablished catalyst design involves a synergistic catalytic effect between hydrogenation-active noble metal sites (e.g., Pt, Rh, Pd, and Ru) and strong oxophilic sites (e.g., MoOx, WOx, and ReOx). This combination promotes the cleavage of the C2–O1 bond in THFA [22–27]. As THFA is more stable than FAL, it is easier to control the selective THFA adsorption configuration on the catalyst surface, consequently obtaining higher selectivities of 1,5-PDO compared to alternative pathways [2]. Nevertheless, the high cost of noble metals and the long reaction times required for the THFA ring opening reduce the techno-economic viability of the system. Alternatively, DHP route involves several consecutive reaction steps and requires the suppression of secondary reactions, which hinders the achievement of 1,5-PDO in a high yield [28]. In contrast to these multistep routes, the furanic ring-opening pathway allows the direct conversion of FAL into 1,5-PDO. Moreover, since FAL is less thermodynamically stable than THFA, its conversion can be accomplished effectively through non noble metals and at lower temperatures and pressures. Typically, a metallic center of Ni0 [28–31], Cu0 [32–34] or Co0 [35] in synergy with an oxophilic metal oxide (e.g., CoOx, MgO or FeOx) is used for the ring-opening. While CoOx metal oxide promotes selectivity of 1,5-PDO, the alkalinity of MgO favors 1,2-PDO. For instance, Liu et al. [32] achieved selectivities of 30.5% and 50% of 1,5-PDO and 1,2-PDO respectively with a Cu0/MgO/Al2O3 mixed metal oxide (MMO) catalyst at 140 °C, 6 MPa of H2 and 8 h of reaction time. Tan et al. [34], on the other hand, developed a Cu0/CoOx/Al2O3 MMO catalyst which obtained a selectivity of 45.5% and 15.9% of 1,5-PDO and 1,2-PDO respectively, at 140 °C, 4 MPa H2 within 2 h. Kurniawan et al. [29], studied a Ni0/CoOx/Al2O3 MMO catalyst which afforded a high yield of 1,5-PDO (47.5%) at 160 °C, 3 MPa H2 within 6 h. However, in direct conversion, the selectivity towards 1,5-PDO product is generally lower than in multistep reactions due to the presence of side reactions. While Ni0-based catalysts generally exhibit higher selectivity toward the byproduct THFA, Cu0 and Co0-based catalysts favor 2-MF and other product selectivities. Therefore, current research for direct conversion of FAL to 1,5-PDO presents the great challenge of controlling the adsorption geometry of FAL, minimizing side reactions, and maximizing selectivity of 1,5-PDO. Moreover, it is desirable that the catalyst design operates under mild conditions in an environmentally friendly solvent. This work aims to achieve a better understanding of the role of each metal component within the MMO containing Cu, Co, Mg, and Al. Although the interactions between Co-Mg [35,36], Cu-Co [16,34,37], and Cu-Mg [33] species have been recently studied for the conversion of FAL into 1,5-PDO, this study unifies all the effects within the tetrametallic CuCoMgAl MMO catalyst and investigates them with the goal of understanding the impact of the different catalytic functionalities on the reaction pathway to develop an improved catalyst (with a high productivity of 17.9 mmol1,5-PDO gcat −1 h−1). The following catalyst variables were examined: (i) the Cu content as a hydrogenating metal; (ii) the Co-to-Mg ratio for the furanic ring opening; and, (iii) the ratio of bivalent-(Cu, Co, and Mg) to-trivalent metals (Al). Moreover, the current study focuses on the enhancement of the catalytic activity and selectivity of 1,5-PDO from direct ring opening of FAL by using a non-noble metallic hydrotalcite derived MMO and ethanol as a green solvent. With the optimized catalytic formulation, the effect of the main operating conditions was analyzed. 2 Methodology 2.1 Materials Copper(II) nitrate hemi(pentahydrate) (Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, 98% purity), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99% purity), magnesium(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, 99% purity), aluminum(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O, 99% purity), ethanol (absolute pure), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, >97% purity), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, >99.5% purity), FUR (98% purity), FAL (98% purity), THFA (98% purity), 1,5-PDO (98% purity), 1,2-PDO (98% purity), 2-MF (98% purity), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (MTHF, ≥99% purity), furan (99% purity), 1-pentanol (1-BOH, ≥99% purity), 2-pentanol (2-POH, 98% purity), 1-butanol (1-BOH, 99% purity), 2-butanol (2-BOH, ≥99% purity), and dodecane (≥99% purity) were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich (Merck). FAL, FUR, 2-MF, and furan were stored at 4 °C and periodically purified by vacuum distillation. Remaining chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of tetrametallic CuxCoyMgzAlw catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation. Subscripts x,y,z,w represent the molar content in Cu, Co, Mg and Al, respectively. In a typical synthesis procedure, a 100 mL 2 M aqueous solution of Na2CO3 was prepared in a stirred vessel. Subsequently, a 100 mL aqueous solution containing the adjusted concentration of metal nitrates was added dropwise. Simultaneously, a 100 mL 2 M aqueous solution of NaOH was employed to control the pH at 10 ± 0.1. The suspension was aged for 24 h at 80 °C, and the solid was filtered and washed with deionized water until the filtrate reached a pH of 7. The resulting hydrotalcite was dried for 24 h at 100 °C. The hydrotalcite was ground and sieved to a particle size of ≤0.2 mm. The MMO was obtained by calcining the hydrotalcite under an air flow of 100 mL min−1 at a temperature of 450 °C for 4 h with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1. Finally, the MMO was reduced under a flow of 100 mL min−1 of 10% H2/N2, at a temperature of 450 °C for 4 h and with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of reduced catalyst samples were obtained with an Xpert-Pro device equipped with a PW3050/60 goniometer and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) working at 40 mA and 40 kV. The patterns were recorded in a 2θ range of 5–70° with scan rate of 0.00167° s−1 using continuous mode spin and room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed to investigate the electronic states of the reduced catalyst. The patterns were obtained with a Physical Electronics PHI 5700 spectrometer with non-monochromatic Mg Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, 1253.6 eV) with a multichannel detector. Spectra were recorded using the constant pass energy mode at 29.35 eV with a 720 μm diameter analysis area. The maximum peak of adventitious carbon was used as the reference for the different peaks (C 1s at binding energy of 284.8 eV). Textural properties were obtained from the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196 °C using an Autosorb iQ3 (Quantachrome, USA). Prior to measurements, reduced samples were outgassed at 300 °C for 3 h under vacuum to remove trapped moisture and other volatile species. Surface areas were calculated by the BET method, and the average pore size and total pore volume by the BJH from desorption points of the isotherms. The surface morphology of the reduced samples was observed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM; FEI Talos F200×) coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (STEM) conducted at 200 kV. Before performing XRD, XPS, STEM, and N2 adsorption–desorption, the catalysts were ex situ-reduced under a 5% H2/Ar flow (40 mL min−1) from room temperature to 450 °C, with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1 and a 4 h isotherm. Following reduction, samples were preserved in isooctane, which served as an inert environment to prevent the formation of oxides when exposed to atmospheric conditions. Just before conducting the characterization tests, the required amount of sample was air-dried for a few minutes until all the volatile isooctane evaporated. The distribution of basic and acid sites was investigated by means of temperature-programmed-desorption (TPD) of CO2 and NH3, respectively employing the previously described AutoChem II. Firstly, 0.1 g of calcined catalyst sample was in situ-reduced under a 5% H2/Ar flow (40 mL min−1) from room temperature to 450 °C with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1 and a 4 h isotherm. Next, the sample was treated at the same temperature with 40 mL min−1 of He for 10 min. For NH3-TPD, the sample was cooled down to 100 °C in He and exposed to a 10% NH3/He flow (25 mL min−1) for 30 min. After that, the sample was kept in He (40 mL min−1) for 30 min to remove the physisorbed ammonia. NH3-TPD was performed by increasing the temperature from 100 °C to 450 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a He flow (15 mL min−1). For CO2-TPD, the sample was initially cooled to 80 °C and exposed to a 5% CO2/He flow for 1 h. Subsequently, the sample was subjected to a pure He flow for 30 min, followed by heating to 140 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The CO2-TPD was performed by raising the temperature from 140 °C to 450 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow rate of 15 mL min−1. The metallic composition of the calcined catalysts was measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using a Perkin-Elmer Optima 2000 instrument. Prior to the analysis, 0.06 g of catalyst sample was digested in a microwave digester (Ethos 1) with an acid mixture of HNO3 and HCl (1:3 in volume ratio). The reduction properties of the calcined catalysts were determined by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a calibrated thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to each H2-TPR, 0.1 g catalyst sample was outgassed in Ar at 200 °C for 1 h to remove impurities. Subsequently, the sample was cooled down to room temperature. H2-TPR was performed by increasing the temperature of the sample to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 5% H2/Ar flow (30 mL min−1). O2-TPD analyses to assess the oxygen vacancies (OVs) were conducted using AutoChem II. 0.1 g of calcined catalyst sample was in situ-reduced under a 5% H2/Ar flow (40 mL min−1) from room temperature to 450 °C with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1 and a 4 h isotherm. The sample was kept at the same temperature with 40 mL min−1 of He for 30 min. Then the sample was cooled to 50 °C and exposed to 5% O2/He flow (40 mL min−1) for 40 min. The analysis was conducted by increasing the temperature from 50 °C to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a He flow (15 mL min−1). N2O-titrations were performed using the AutoChem II. Before the analysis, catalyst sample was in situ-reduced at 450 °C at a heating rate of 4 °C min−1 under a 5% H2/Ar flow (30 mL min−1) for 4 h. After cooling in a He flow to 35 °C, the sample was exposed to He for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed H2. The sample was subsequently heated to 60 °C and exposed to a 5% N2O/He flow (25 mL min−1) for 1 h, thereby oxidizing metallic Cu centers and Coδ+/OV species, according to Eqs. (1) and (2). Afterwards, the sample was cooled to −10 °C in Ar and waited until the TCD baseline stabilized. Finally, H2-TPR was conducted by increasing the temperature of the sample to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 5% H2/Ar flow. (1) 2Cu + N 2 O → Cu 2 O + N 2 (3) C o δ + + OV + N 2 O → C o δ + + O l a t t i c e + N 2 The hydrogenating capacity of the catalysts was evaluated by H2 pulse chemisorption with the AutoChem II. Firstly, 0.025 g of calcined catalyst sample was in situ-reduced under a 5% H2/Ar flow (40 mL min−1) from room temperature to 450 °C with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1 and a 4 h isotherm. The sample was purged with Ar for 1 h and cooled down to room temperature. The H2 pulse chemisorption was performed using H2/Ar pulses of 20 mL every 3.5 min until the catalyst was saturated with H2. Meanwhile, the catalyst was exposed to a flow of 50 mL min−1 of Ar. CO-DRIFT was performed to characterize Cu sites. The catalyst was mixed with KBr at a weight ratio of 1:5. The catalyst was in situ-reduced in the DRIFT cell at 450 °C under a 5% H2/N2 flow (100 mL min−1), with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1 and a 4 h isotherm. Next, the cell was flushed with N2 at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1 for 30 min and then cooled to ambient temperature. Background spectra were recorded. Subsequently, the cell was flushed using 10% CO/N2 at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1 for 30 min. Finally, the gas flow was switched to N2 (10 mL min−1) and CO-DRIFT spectra were recorded after flushing at 30 °C for 20 min. To investigate the stability and carbon deposition on the fresh and spent Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under N2 and O2 flows using a TG209 thermogravimetric analyzer (Netzsch). Both ex situ-reduced samples were stored in isooctane to prevent oxidation under atmospheric conditions. Prior to analysis, the catalysts were dried under a 30 mL min−1 N2 flow and weighed in an inert environment. For the N2-TGA analysis, the sample was heated to 900 °C under a 30 mL min−1 N2 flow with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1. In the O2-TGA analysis, the samples were first heated to 800 °C under a 30 mL min−1 N2 flow with a heating ramp of 4 °C min−1 to remove any chemisorbed species. Subsequently, the samples were cooled to 80 °C and then heated to 900 °C at a rate of 4 °C min−1 under a 21% O2/N2 flow (50 mL min−1). 2.4 Catalytic activity and product analysis In a typical FAL hydrogenation experiment, 0.4 g FAL, 10 mL ethanol, and 0.025 g catalyst were added to a 30-mL stainless steel batch reactor with a magnetically driven stirrer. The ex situ-reduced catalyst, stored in isooctane to prevent oxidation under atmospheric conditions, was air-dried for a few minutes until all the isooctane evaporated, before being added to the reactor. The reactor was sealed, purged three times with H2, and then pressurized to 30 bar with H2 at room temperature. Subsequently, the reactor was heated to the required temperature (140−180 °C), leading to an increase in total system pressure due to the thermal expansion of H2 and ethanol vapor pressure. Once the temperature was reached, the stirring rate was set to 500 rpm. The reactor pressure was kept constant by connecting a hydrogen line regulated to the corresponding pressure at the selected reaction temperature (e.g., 54 bar at 160 °C), allowing continuous H2 feeding to compensate for its consumption during the reaction. After the reaction (0.5–5h), stirring was stopped, and the reactor was cooled to 50 °C. The solid–liquid mixture was filtered through 0.22-µm PTFE filter. Before analysis, 0.12 g dodecane were added to the liquid mixture as an internal standard for gas-chromatography analysis. Liquid products were analyzed in an Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph with a DB-1 column (60 m × 530 µm × 5 µm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The liquid and gaseous compounds were identified using the Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 with a TRB-WAX column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.1 µm). FAL conversion, product selectivity, and product yield were calculated according to Eqs. (3), (4) and (5), respectively. To ensure reproducibility, experiments were conducted in duplicate, repeating runs if deviations were observed. For the main catalysts (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 and Cu0.2Co3.8Al1), triplicate experiments allowed for the calculation of standard deviation. (3) Conversion (%) = 1- final FAL moles initial FAL moles × 100 (4) Selectivity (%) = moles of product moles of reacted FAL × 100 (5) Yield (%) = moles of product initial FAL moles × 100 Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were determined to evaluate catalytic performance based on both the total reactant consumption and the specific production of 1,5-PDO. The number of active sites (A.S.) was estimated using N2O titration. TOF values were calculated using Eqs. (6) and (7) for a reaction time of 1 h, ensuring that conversions remained below 20%. (6) TOF = moles of reacted FAL moles of active sites × reaction time (7) TOF 1,5-PDO = moles of produced 1,5-PDO moles of active sites × reaction time 3 Results and discussion As mentioned in the introduction, three different catalytic series were synthesized to investigate the role of each metal present in the CuxCoyMgzAlw material: (i) the Co-to-Mg molar ratio, (ii) the Cu molar content, and (iii) the divalent metals (Cu, Co, Mg) to trivalent metal (Al) ratio. In each series, a single variable was modified while the other two remained constant. The constant values were a Co-to-Mg molar ratio of 3:1, a Cu to other divalent metals molar ratio of 0.2:3.8, and a divalent to trivalent metal molar ratio of 4:1. The following sections present the characterization and activity results for these three series. 3.1 Catalyst characterization H2-TPR was performed to determine the reducibility of the catalysts (Fig. 2 ). Fig. 2a shows H2-TPR spectra for the different Co-to-Mg ratio catalyst series. The catalyst without Co (Cu0.2Mg3.8Al1) exhibits a low-temperature (267 °C) peak attributed to the reduction of CuO to Cu0 and a broad weak peak at high-temperature (461 °C) associated with the reduction of Cu within the CuAl2O4 spinel [38,39]. For Co-containing catalysts, peaks at low-to-medium temperatures are observed (178–273 °C), which are associated with the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, followed by the reduction of CoO to Co0 [16,29], or its conversion to Coδ+/OV at 417–489 °C. This is supported by complementary techniques such as XRD (Fig. S1 and the corresponding discussion in the Supporting Information) and XPS (Fig. 3 ), which show no evidence of Co0 at a catalyst reduction temperature of 450 °C. Higher temperature peaks (626−698 °C) are attributed to the reduction of Co2+ ions within the structural framework of CoAl2O4 [37,40]. The increase in the Co-to-Mg ratio in the catalyst formulation led to the shift of the Cu and Co reduction temperatures to lower-temperature regions, probably due to a strong Cu-Co interaction [9]. For the different Cu content catalytic series (Fig. 2b), it is observed that the increase in Cu content significantly promotes the reduction of Co species, shifting the reduction peaks to lower temperatures. This is attributed to the metallic Cu, which activates and spills over hydrogen, facilitating the reduction of Co species [37]. This effect is also observed in the XRD results (Fig. S1), where the CoO signal decreases as the Cu content increases. For the catalyst without Cu (Co3Mg1Al1), two distinct peaks are observed at low temperature (<450 °C) and two at high temperature (>450 °C). In both temperature ranges, the initial peaks are attributed to Co with a weaker interaction with alumina, while the second peak corresponds to Co that interacts with Al ions through O2 interconnections [29]. For the different bivalent-to-trivalent ratio catalyst series (Fig. 2c), a shift in the reduction peaks towards lower temperatures is observed as the alumina content decreases. Notably, the catalyst without alumina (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95) exhibits the lowest reduction temperatures. This can be attributed to the fact that Al interacts with Co and Cu species, preventing the migration of cobalt species, hence increasing the reduction temperatures [29]. Moreover, as the Al content decreases, Cu0 content increases, which aids in reducing the catalyst. The basicity and acidity results for the reduced catalysts are collected in Table 1 . The CO2 and NH3 species adsorbed on the MMO surface can be categorized into three regions: weak (< 200 °C), medium (200–350 °C), and strong sites (350–450 °C). On the one hand, weak basicity is attributed to the desorption of CO2 from weak Brønsted OH− groups, medium basicity is ascribed to the desorption from Co2+– O2−, Mg2+– O2− and Al3+– O2− pairs, and strong basic sites are associated with CO2 bounded with low coordination O2− anions [33,39]. On the other hand, weak acidity is related to Co2+, Mg2+, and Al3+ Lewis acid sites, medium acidity is attributed to interaction of NH3 with Al3+ sites of Al2O3 and Al2O3 spinels, and strong acidity is ascribed to NH3 coordination to coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (Coδ+/OV) [27,41]. In the catalyst series with different Co-to-Mg ratios, it is observed that an increase in Mg content leads to a rise in the number of basic sites in the catalysts. This is attributed to the presence of the O2− ion in the MgO species, which exhibits a higher Lewis basicity than CoO due to the highly ionic nature of the Mg–O bond [42]. In the Cu-content catalyst series, as the Cu loading increases, the reduction temperature of the catalyst decreases. This leads to a reduction in oxidized species and, consequently, a decrease in overall basicity. Similarly, in the bivalent-to-trivalent ratio catalyst series, a decrease in aluminum content correlates with reduced basicity, particularly in medium and strong basic centers. This is again related to the improved reducibility as the Al content decreases, in agreement with the H2-TPR results (Fig. 2c), which indicate a reduction in the number of oxygen sites. With regard to acid site distribution in the catalysts, it is observed that the amount of strong acid sites is directly proportional to the Co content (Co-to-Mg ratio series). This is due to the greater number of Coδ+ sites adjacent to an OV generated through the reduction of Co oxides. This is corroborated by the results obtained through TPD-O2 (Fig. 4 a). Furthermore, with the rise in Cu content (Cu content series), an increase in total acidity is presented. While the increase in medium acid sites is attributed to CuAl2O4 (Cu2+) spinel [43,44], the increase in strong acid sites is associated with the increase in Coδ+/OV sites produced by the promotion of the catalyst reduction by Cu0 species. Lastly, as Al content decreases (bivalent-to-trivalent ratio series), the number of acid sites in the catalyst becomes significantly higher. This may be due to the rise in catalyst reducibility as the Al content decreases (see H2-TPR results, Fig. 2c), resulting in a greater number of Coδ+/OV sites. Conversely, in the absence of Al, acidity is greatly reduced, which may be related to the reduced surface area and to the agglomeration of the metals. XPS measurements were carried out to determine the valence states of Cu and Co in the catalysts (Fig. 3). XPS analyses were performed to validate the results and conclusions obtained in the H2-TPR (Fig. 2) and XRD (Fig. S1) techniques. Therefore, the study was only performed on the key catalysts for this purpose. In the Cu 2p XPS profiles, the peaks located at a binding energy of 932.8 eV and 952.9 eV are assigned to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of the metallic Cu, respectively. Although the Cu2+ signal is not clearly detected, for the catalysts containing Al, very weak satellites at 943.0 eV and 960.9 eV corresponding to Cu2+ are observed. This is likely due to the dissolution of Cu2+ into alumina [45], forming CuAl2O4, which requires higher temperatures for reduction than CuO. This observation is consistent with the H2-TPR and XRD results, which also indicate the presence of the CuAl2O4 phase. For the O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 3b), the peak at 530.5 eV is attributed to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) [46], whereas the peak at 531.4 eV is associated with OVs [47,48]. The Cu0.2Mg3.8Al1 catalyst does not exhibit a distinct OV peak, likely due to the absence of reducible Co species, which would otherwise create coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+/OV sites when exposed to high temperatures and a hydrogen flow. Additionally, no evidence of OV formation adjacent to Cu2+ is observed, as Cu is fully reduced to Cu0, as confirmed by Fig. 3a. Similarly, the Co3Mg1Al1 catalyst does not present the OV peak, which could be attributed to the incomplete reduction of Co species, as suggested by the H2-TPR results (Fig. 2b). On the other hand, the Cu0.6Co2.55Mg0.85Al1 catalyst exhibits a weaker overall O 1s signal and a slightly larger OV area than Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1, possibly due to the greater reducibility of Cu0.6Co2.55Mg0.85Al1, given its higher Cu content. Moreover, the catalyst without Al (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95) displays the weakest O 1s signal and the highest OV peak. This behavior is attributed to its higher reducibility (Fig. 2c) and the lower amount of Olatt, which results from the absence of the non-reducible Al2O3 phase. In the Co XPS profiles, the peaks at 780.0 eV and 795.8 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+ in the CoO phase or in the Coδ+/OV sites, while the peaks at 781.9 and 796.6 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+ in the CoAl2O4 phase [29,49]. Even for the catalyst without Cu (Co3Mg1Al1), which decreases the reducibility of the Co phases, the peak corresponding to Co3+ is not detected, consistent with the findings from H2-TPR (Fig. 2b) and XRD (Fig. 1S) analyses. In the case of the catalyst without Al (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95), the Co2+ peak corresponding to the CoO or Coδ+/OV species shifts to a higher energy of 781.5 eV. Additionally, the peak observed at 925.8 eV, which overlaps with the Cu spectrum, is attributed to Co2+ in the Co 2s region [50,51]. Although according to TPR results, CoO should be partially reduced at 450 °C in catalysts containing Cu, no Co0 is detected by either XRD (Fig. 1S) or XPS. This suggests that, under a hydrogen atmosphere, the reduction of CoO in this catalyst leads to the formation of Coδ+/OV species rather than metallic Co0. The total number of metal sites active for oxygen activation was investigated through N2O titration (Table 2 ). The number of N2O activation sites increases with the Cu content. As observed in the H2-TPR results (Fig. 2b), the reducibility of the catalysts improves with increasing Cu content, promoting the reduction of Co oxides and increasing the Coδ+/OV sites. Therefore, increasing the Cu loading in the catalyst increases the amount of Cu0 and Coδ+/OV sites capable of activating N2O. To amount of H2 activation sites was estimated by H2 chemisorption (Table 2). Although the trend is the same as the N2O titration results, exhibiting an increase in the H2 activation sites with Cu loading, there is almost a two-order-of-magnitude difference. This indicates that the synthesized materials show a significantly higher proportion of oxygen activations sites than H2 activation sites. O2-TPD analyses were conducted to evaluate the OV sites on the pre-reduced catalyst surfaces of Co-to-Mg series (Fig. 4a). The oxygen species desorbed from the metal oxides were classified as follows: physically adsorbed and superoxide oxygen (O2(ads)), monoatomic oxygen (O(ads)), surface lattice oxygen (Olatt(surface)) and bulk oxygen (Olatt (bulk)). To qualitatively estimate the contribution of each oxygen species, the O2-TPD profiles were deconvoluted. To identify the bulk lattice oxygen contribution, blank experiments were performed without prior O2 exposure of the samples, allowing quantification of the Olatt (bulk) signal. The remaining peaks were assigned based on temperature ranges: desorption below 200 °C was attributed to O2(ads), peaks between 200–400 °C to O(ads), and peaks above 400 °C–after subtracting the Olatt (bulk) signal–were assigned to Olatt(surface) [29,52]. The catalyst with no Co (i.e., Cu0.2Mg3.8Al1) shows a lack of Olatt(surface), suggesting an absence of OV. This is associated with the fact that MgO is not reducible at 450 °C, unlike the Co oxide species. The Olatt(surface) related to the OV sites increases with the Co content in the catalyst. This is attributed to the reduction of Co oxides, leading to the creation of OV sites neighboring coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ sites. Finally, to investigate the effect of Al content in the surface arrangement of active metallic Cu, CO-DRIFTS profiles were collected for the reduced divalent-to-trivalent metal ratio catalyst series (Fig. 4b). The sharp peaks centered at 2100–2115 cm−1 are assigned to linearly adsorbed CO on individual Cu0 sites. The peak area does not vary significantly among the catalysts. The catalyst without Al (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95) exhibits a peak at 2000 cm−1 with a shoulder at 1960 cm−1, which is attributed to CO bonded to surface Cu0-clustered atoms in the bridged and 3-fold hollow-bonded forms. Since this adsorption configuration typically occurs on larger Cu aggregates rather than well-dispersed single sites, this suggests that, without Al, Cu tends to form larger clusters with lower dispersion [29]. In contrast, alumina incorporation during catalyst preparation inhibits Cu particle growth by promoting the formation of a hydrotalcite-like precursor. Upon calcination and reduction, this leads to a more uniform metal distribution across the catalyst surface [53,54]. This is further corroborated by the images obtained from HR-TEM and EDS analysis (Fig. S3), which indicate an uneven surface in the absence of Al (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95), whereas Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst presents a homogeneous distribution of metals. Moreover, the surface area increases with Al content, from 66 m2 g−1 in the absence of Al to 167.3 m2 g−1 for Cu0.15Co2.14Mg0.71Al1 catalyst. 3.2 Reaction route for main products formation Within the operating temperature range of 140–180 °C, a wide range of reaction products was observed with the CuxCoyMgzAlw catalysts (Fig. 5 ). Starting from FAL, four primary parallel reaction pathways were identified: (1) ring opening hydrogenolysis to 1,5-PDO and 1,2-PDO, (2) hydrogenolysis of the C1–O2 bond in the alcohol group to 2-MF, (3) furan ring hydrogenation to THFA, and (4) conversion of FAL to furan. When 2-MF was used as the reactant, the following products were detected: 1-pentanol (1-POH), 2-pentanol (2-POH), 2-butanol (2-BOH), 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO), pentane, butane, and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF). All of these compounds are grouped under the term 2-MFd, such that the overall selectivity to 2-MFd remains constant over time (see Fig. S4), similarly to 1,5-PDO, 1,2-PDO, 1-BOH, and THFA. Feeding the ring opening products (1,5-PDO, 1,2-PDO, 1-POH, 2-POH, 1-BOH and 2-BOH) individually as reactants, further hydrogenation occurred for large reaction times, producing volatile alkanes (Fig. S5). The opening of the THFA ring was not observed over the studied catalysts, as this molecule was stable and no products were detected when fed as reactant. Previous studies reported the conversion of 2-MTHF to yield 2-BOH [28]. However, as with THFA, the opening of the unsaturated ring is not feasible with this tetrametallic catalyst type under the operating conditions studied. Starting from FUR as the reactant, an increase in the production of 1-BOH derived from FUR hydrogenolysis was observed. However, the production of CO derived from the conversion of FUR into furan as an intermediate product in the conversion to 1-BOH was not observed. It is associated with CO hydrogenation to methanol [55], which was detected over the tetrametallic catalysts. In addition, a slight increase in selectivity to 2-MFd was also observed when FUR was fed as a reagent instead of FAL. This can be attributed to the direct hydrogenolysis of FUR to 2-MF with the synergistic effect between metal sites and Lewis acid sites, without FAL formation as the intermediate [56]. As discussed in more detail in Section 3.3, the nature of the catalytic sites determines the preference for different reaction pathways. Acid sites, primarily associated with Coδ+/OV, promote hydrogenolysis reactions. Consequently, selectivity toward products derived from –CH2OH bond cleavage in FAL (such as 1-BOH and 2-MFd) increases. As previously shown in the characterization section, acidity is enhanced in CuxCoyMgzAlw catalysts by: (i) a high Co-to-Mg molar ratio, (ii) a high Cu content, and (iii) a low divalent-to-trivalent metal ratio. FAL is believed to adsorb preferentially via its hydroxyl group onto Coδ+/OV sites, facilitating its hydrogenolysis [56]. Notably, the Cu0.2Co3.8Al1 catalyst, which exhibited the highest selectivity toward 1-BOH and 2-MFd, also showed the greatest number of strong acid sites, according to NH3-TPD measurements. This correlation supports the role of Coδ+/OV sites in driving –CH2OH bond cleavage. On the other hand, the sites that promote the hydrogenation of FAL to THFA are basic in nature, originating from coordinated Co2+–O2−, Mg2+–O2−, and Al3+–O2− pairs. In these catalysts, basicity is inversely proportional to acidity and is favored under the following conditions: (i) low Co-to-Mg molar ratio, (ii) low Cu content, and (iii) high divalent-to-trivalent metal ratio, as discussed in more detail in the characterization section. For instance, the Cu0.2Co0.95Mg2.85Al1 catalyst, characterized by a high abundance of Lewis basic Mg2+–O2− pairs and non-reduced Co2+–O2− species—as evidenced by CO2-TPD and TPR results—exhibited high selectivity toward THFA. However, to maximize the selectivity toward the hydrogenolysis of FAL to 1,5-PDO, a balance between acidic and basic functionalities is required, as discussed in Section 3.3, while simultaneously minimizing the formation of byproducts such as 2-MFd, 1-BOH, and THFA. 3.3 Catalytic results and structure–activity relationship Table 3 summarizes FAL reaction conversions, product selectivities, and carbon balance (CBalance) values over the different catalysts in ethanol at 160 °C, under an operating H2 pressure of 54 bar. Focusing first on the Co-to-Mg catalytic series, in the absence of Co in the catalyst (Cu0.2Mg3.8Al1), poor catalytic activity is obtained (3.2%), which closely resembles the conversion achieved when there is no catalyst (1.8%). It is observed that an increase in the Co-to-Mg ratio leads to an enhancement in catalytic activity, reaching a maximum conversion of 80.1% when no Mg is present in the catalyst (Cu0.2Co3.8Al1). Moreover, there is a linear relationship between the Co-to-Mg ratio and the TOF (Fig. 6 a). These results are further corroborated when studying the evolution of FAL conversion and product yield over time for the Cu0.2Co3.8Al1 and Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalysts, shown in Fig. 6c and Fig. 6d, respectively. The catalyst without Mg (Cu0.2Co3.8Al1) exhibits higher catalytic activity, achieving 100% conversion within 3 h, whereas the Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst reaches full conversion in 4 h. For both catalysts, the conversion increases linearly over time, suggesting zero-order reaction kinetics. These results indicate that Co species play a key role in activating the FAL molecule. This is likely due to the reduction of Co oxides, which generates coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ sites adjacent to OVs, as supported by NH3-TPD and O 1s XPS results. These Coδ+ sites act as strong Lewis acid sites and are active for C2–O1 bond adsorption [29,36,57]. Therefore, higher Co content leads to a greater number of strong Coδ+ acid sites and consequently to enhanced catalytic activity. Furthermore, a combination of Coδ+ and O2− sites is capable of promoting hydrogen activation and spillover by facilitating hydride donation to coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ species and proton binding to the basic coordinated oxygen anions [58,59]. The selectivity towards 1,5-PDO is greatly influenced by the Co-to-Mg ratio, reaching a maximum value of 43.8% for a Co:Mg ratio of 3:1. On the one hand, an increase in the Co-to-Mg ratio, which is directly proportional to the number of acid sites according to the NH3-TPD characterization results (see Table 1), enhances the selectivity of the 2-MFd pathway. As a result, a maximum 2-MFd selectivity of 23.8% is obtained when no Mg is present (Cu0.2Co3.8Al1), thereby reducing the selectivity towards 1,5-PDO. This is attributed to the ability of acid sites to promote the hydrogenolysis of the C1–O2 bond, leading to the selective production of 2-MF [9,60]. Acid sites can act as active sites for the FAL hydroxyl (−OH) group adsorption to form a methylene intermediate. This intermediate is then hydrogenated by the nearby metallic centers to form 2-MF [56,61]. On the other hand, a low Co-to-Mg ratio, which correlates directly with the basic sites according to the CO2-TPD characterization results (see Table 1), leads to an increase in THFA selectivity. A maximum THFA selectivity of 50.2% is obtained at a Co-to-Mg ratio of 1 to 3 (Cu0.2Co0.95Mg2.85Al1) catalyst, thereby reducing 1,5-PDO selectivity as well. The increase in the basic sites promotes the flat adsorption of the furan ring, which is reported to selectively produce THFA [12,62,63]. Consequently, an optimal Co-to-Mg molar ratio of 3:1 (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1) is established to maximize selectivity towards 1,5-PDO. This is because Coδ+ acid sites adjacent to OVs are necessary for the cleavage of FAL and ring opening to form 1,5-PDO. However, excess acidity in the catalyst favors the selectivity of 2-MFd over 1,5-PDO. This is further verified by the TOF referred to the 1,5-PDO mol production (TOF1,5-PDO) (Fig. 6a), which presents an optimum value of 27.4 mol1,5-PDO mol−1 A.S. h−1 for the Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst. Additionally, Fig. 6c and Fig. 6d show that the Mg-containing catalyst (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1) decreases 2-MFd yield, thereby maximizing 1,5-PDO production compared to the Cu0.2Co3.8Al1 catalyst. A minor 1% drop in 1,5-PDO yield is observed for the Cu0.2Co3.8Al1 catalyst when extending the reaction time from 3 to 4 h. This decline is associated with the hydrogenolysis of 1,5-PDO to 1-POH. However, this effect was not observed for the Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst, even after 8 h of reaction. Interestingly, the catalyst without Co, Cu0.2Mg3.8Al1, showed very low activity but high selectivity towards 1,2-PDO. This could be attributed to another reaction mechanism involving hydroxyl group adsorption onto basic sites generated by MgO [32,33]. Regarding the Cu-content catalyst series results, the catalyst without Cu (Co3Mg1Al1) presents very poor catalytic activity (3.8%). As the Cu molar content in the tetrametallic catalyst increased from 0.1 to 0.6, the conversion increased from 21.2% to 62.5% respectively. Although the catalyst without Cu (Co3Mg1Al1) is expected to contain Coδ+ centers, according to H2-chemisorption and H2-TPD measurements, which showed that there was a small number of H2 activation sites, it is not capable of efficiently converting FAL. Metallic Cu sites enhance the catalyst hydrogenation capacity and facilitate cobalt reduction, as previously shown in the H2-TRP results, leading to the generation of additional Coδ+ sites. Moreover, the increase in the Cu content leads to an increase in the overall adsorbed and activated hydrogen, promoting FAL hydrogenolysis. This is attributed to hydrogen atoms, which can induce the cleavage of the C2–O1 bond, and furthermore, after the ring opening, 1,5-PDO is formed through the hydrogenation of the corresponding unsaturated bonds [29]. Nevertheless, it is found that the catalytic activity, as well as the hydrogenation capability of the catalyst (Table 2), are non-linear with respect to Cu content. The results show an optimum TOF of 72.4 molreac. mol−1 A.S. h−1 for a Cu0.2 content (Fig. 6d). At higher Cu contents, the TOF values remain almost constant. However, for the lower Cu0.1 content, a sharp decrease in TOF is observed. This may be attributed to the limited interaction between Cu0 centers and Coδ+/OV sites. A possible explanation is that below a certain density of Cu0 sites, hydrogen spillover to Coδ+/OV may be restricted. The selectivity for 1,5-PDO is negatively affected by the Cu content, decreasing from 45.8% to 35.4% at 0.1 and 0.6 Cu content, respectively, while 2-MFd selectivity increases to a maximum of 18.6% at Cu0.6. This is attributed to the increase in the number of acid sites with higher Cu content (Table 1), which promotes 2-MFd selectivity. Additionally, it is reported that metallic Cu particles can adsorb the FAL molecule through its hydroxyl group, while maintaining the furan ring perpendicular, without the adsorption of the C2–O1 bond, thus promoting 2-MF production [43,64]. This is further corroborated by the TOF1,5-PDO data (Fig. 6d), which shows a maximum of 26.7 mol1,5-PDO mol−1 A.S. h−1 at Cu0.2, with a decrease at higher Cu contents. Finally, with respect to the divalent-to-trivalent ratio, the catalytic activity improves as the Al content in the catalyst is reduced, reaching a maximum conversion of 67.8% for a divalent metals to Al metal molar ratio of 8:1 (Cu0.4Co5.7Mg1.9Al1). The reduction in Al content results in an increase in catalyst acidity (Table 1), particularly in weak and strong acid sites. Strong acid sites are directly related to the coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ species, which are active in the cleavage of the FAL C2–O1 bond. Moreover, by increasing the divalent-metals-to-Al-metal ratio, thereby raising the Co and Cu load in the catalyst (Table S1), an increase in the number of species that can activate H2 (Cu0 and Coδ+/OV) is expected according to the H2-TPR results (Fig. 2c). Therefore, it is likely that the hydrogenation capability of the catalyst increases as the divalent-metals-to-Al-metal ratio increases. However, the catalyst without Al (Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95) exhibits a lower conversion rate of 52.1%, which is attributed to the agglomeration of the Cu0 phase, as observed through STEM analysis (Fig. S3) and a lower catalytic surface area (Table S1). Without Al, the hydrotalcite-like precursor, which enhances the homogeneity and surface area of the resulting MMO, is not formed. The maximum 1,5-PDO selectivity of 43% is achieved with an optimal divalent metals to Al metal ratio of 4:1. As the Al content in the catalyst is reduced, acidity is enhanced, which, in turn, enhances the selectivity for 2-MFd. The selective production of THFA over the Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95 catalyst is attributed to extensive furan ring saturation at the Cu0 sites. Thus, higher Al content inhibits furan ring saturation while promoting the cleavage of the C2–O1 bond in FAL. The optimized Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst is compared with similar mixed metal oxide catalysts from the literature (Table S2). To highlight the advancements of this tetrametallic catalyst, the productivity of 1,5-PDO is calculated (17.9 mmol1,5-PDO gcat −1h−1), showing a higher value than that of the reported catalyst. Additionally, it operates at a higher FAL concentration than in previous reports. As demonstrated in the discussion of the effect of main reaction parameters in the Supporting Information, this increase in concentration reduces the selectivity of 1,5-PDO from 54.4% at 1 wt.% to 43.8% at 4.8 wt.%. 3.4 Catalyst stability The stability of the optimized Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst was evaluated through four consecutive FAL reactions with each cycle carried out over a 30-minute reaction time. After each run, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed with isooctane, without direct exposure to air during the process in order to prevent possible oxidation. As shown in the activity and selectivity results (Fig. 7 a), a slight decrease in catalytic activity was observed, from 38.7% conversion in the first cycle to 34.1% in the fourth. However, the product distribution remained stable, with an average selectivity of 44.5% toward 1,5-PDO. To investigate the cause of this minor decrease in conversion, the catalyst was characterized using NH3-TPD (Table S3), N2 adsorption–desorption (Table S3), and N2- and O2-TGA (Fig. 7b and Fig. 7c, respectively). No significant structural changes were detected, as the SBET and pore volume remained consistent for the spent catalyst. However, a slight reduction in acid sites was observed, particularly in the strong acid sites associated with Coδ+/OV, which could be related to poisoning of the Coδ+/OV active sites by carbonaceous deposition. To confirm this, N2 and O2-TGA analyses were conducted. In N2-TGA, only the spent catalyst exhibited a noticeable weight loss, attributed to the desorption of FAL and other chemisorbed species. In O2-TGA (catalysts pretreated at 800 °C under N2, see Section 2.3.), both fresh and spent catalysts showed weight gain due to the oxidation of Coδ+/OV sites and reduced species such as Cu⁰. However, the weight increase for the spent catalyst was lower, suggesting that part of the weight loss was due to the combustion of carbonaceous species that could not be desorbed in N2, even at high temperatures (800 °C). 4 Conclusions This study investigates the direct hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol over a series of tetrametallic Cu/CoOx/MgO/Al2O3 catalysts in ethanol. The role of each metal and the influence of acid–base properties on catalytic activity and product selectivity were thoroughly examined. Co species are shown to play a central role in catalytic performance. Upon reduction, Co oxides generate coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ sites adjacent to oxygen vacancies, which act as strong Lewis acid centers. These sites promote the adsorption and activation of furfuryl alcohol, facilitating the cleavage of the carbon–oxygen bond in the furan ring and enabling ring-opening reactions. However, an excess of Co increases the overall acidity and favors the undesired formation of 2-methylfuran via hydrogenolysis of the hydroxymethyl group. The incorporation of MgO helps suppress this side reaction. Mg provides basic sites that reduce the total acidity of the catalyst and shift the selectivity toward 1,5-pentanediol. Nonetheless, excessive basicity promotes hydrogenation of the furan ring, leading to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol as a byproduct. An optimal Co-to-Mg molar ratio of 3:1 was identified to achieve the best balance between activity and selectivity. Cu plays a dual role in the system. Cu0 acts as a site for molecular hydrogen dissociation and facilitates hydrogen spillover toward the Co species. It also promotes the reduction of Co oxides at lower temperatures, enhancing the formation of active Coδ+/oxygen vacancy sites. However, higher Cu loadings contribute to increased acidity, which again enhances 2-methylfuran formation. A Cu molar content of 0.2 was found to be optimal. The addition of Al2O3 contributes to improved metal dispersion and structural stability. It prevents excessive growth of Cu0 particles and reduces over-hydrogenation of the furan ring, thereby limiting the formation of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. However, a high Al2O3 content decreases the overall reducibility of the catalyst, lowering the concentration of active sites. An optimal divalent-to-trivalent metal ratio of 4:1 was identified to maximize 1,5-pentanediol selectivity. The optimized Cu0.2Co2.85Mg0.95Al1 catalyst formulation showed a high yield of 1,5-PDO of 43.8% under a total pressure of 54 bar, at 160 °C for 4 h in ethanol, achieving a TOF of 27.4 mol1,5-PDO mol−1 A.S. h−1. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol is investigated over a tetrametallic Cu/CoOx/MgO/Al2O3 catalytic system. Activity and characterization results suggest the specific roles of each metal: Cu0 dissociates H2, whereas CoOx, as a reducible oxide, generates Coδ+ sites next to oxygen vacancies where furfuryl alcohol adsorbs. Activated hydrogen spills over from Cu0 to these coordinatively unsaturated Coδ+ sites, enabling the hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol. Furthermore, Cu0 aids in the reduction of Co oxide species at lower temperatures during the catalyst activation, thereby promoting the generation of uncoordinated Coδ+ sites. The presence of MgO decreases overall acidity, resulting in reduced hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol to 2-methylfuran and increased selectivity towards 1,5-pentanediol. Finally, the presence of Al2O3 in the catalyst enhances metal dispersion, reducing the furanic ring hydrogenation to yield tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. With the optimized catalyst, a 43.8% 1,5-pentanediol yield is obtained at 160 °C for 4 h in ethanol, achieving a TOF of 27.4 mol1,5-PDO mol−1 A.S. h−1.
